[date of source: August 7, 2007
Finding aid encoded by Valerie Higgins, Library/Archives, Indiana University, February 10, 2009

did.head: Summary Information
did.abstract: The Bradbury, M. mss. II, 1949-1993, consists of the papers of British author, professor, and literary critic Malcolm Bradbury, 1932-2000.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: After teaching fellowships in America at Indiana University and Yale, Malcolm Bradbury began his career as a professor the same week his first novel Eating People Is Wrong was published in 1959. Much of his creative writing concerns academic subjects, and his critical works reflect his interests in American Studies, Modernism, and Postmodernism. In 1965 Bradbury became a lecturer at the University of East Anglia in Norwich, England, and helped create its American Studies department, where he was named a professor in 1970. In 1975 The Royal Society of Literature awarded his novel, The History Man, the Heinemann Prize, and his next novel, Rates of Exchange, was shortlisted for the Booker Prize in 1983. In addition to novels and critical work, Bradbury has adapted several novels into scripts for the BBC, as well as creating and writing original programs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into the following series: I. Correspondence; II. Writings; III. Miscellaneous.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Bradbury, M. mss. II, 1949-1993, consists of the papers of British author, professor, and literary critic Malcolm Bradbury, 1932-2000. The papers contain correspondence with many of Bradbury's contemporaries in British fiction and academics, as well as his agents, publishers, and family. The writings contain many drafts of his novels and critical works, along with research notes and some background material. There are also drafts of books edited by Bradbury. Miscellaneous materials include items related to his teaching, lecturing, and activities with various organizations and committees, as well as financial papers, including royalty statements.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Bradbury, M. mss.; also located at the Lilly Library, Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: Photocopying permitted only with permission of the Curator of Manuscripts, Lilly Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], Bradbury M. mss. II, Lilly Library, Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana.

scopecontent.p: The correspondence consists of a chronological file from 1949-1993, plus an alphabetical file of correspondents selected by Bradbury. Among the correspondents in the chronological file are Bradbury's family, literary agents, publishers, academic colleagues, magazine editors, and students. The correspondents in this file have not been listed or indexed. The alphabetical file is mostly Bradbury's friends and fellow writers. A list of these correspondents is available.

item.persname: Kinross, John Patrick Douglas Balfour, 3rd baron, 1904-1976

scopecontent.p: The writings consist of typescripts, carbons, proofs, and handwritten notes, with annotations by Bradbury, his wife, and his editors. They are arranged in the following series: I. Fiction, humor and critical works, including early writings, novels, short stories, humor, parodies, and critical works; II. Works edited by Bradbury; including volumes of short stories and critical essays; III. Drama, including scripts for revues, radio, television and film; IV. Book reviews, by Bradbury; V. A travel diary; VI. Printed items, including clippings, tearsheets and offprints; VII. Writings by others.

arrangement.p: After Early Writings, works are arranged by publication date.
